title.narrative: Local Development Finance For Inclusive Growth: The Role Of Innovative Municipal Finance And Management In Achieving Local Sustainability (Uncdf Project)

description.narrative:
Strong and capable institutions are critical for sustainable urban development. Improved governance processes are at the core of sustainable management and planning of cities and towns. Laws and policies have to be adapted to the local needs. UN-Habitat is working through this project to develop and reinforce a conducive and enabling environment, which requires adequate legal frameworks, political, managerial and administrative process, mechanisms, guidelines and tools to respond to the needs of the population and its local representatives.
The project addresses one of the main issue of the Local Government for Sustainable Urban Development Umbrella project
The need to ensure municipal financial sustainability with accountable leadership
Municipal finances are central to local governments, as their strategic management plays a critical role in ensuring long-term sustainability of local services. One key issue faced by local governments is how to expand their resource base beyond central-to-local transfers. Stakeholders are keen to integrate new ideas/tools on expenditure management, tax base identification, local tax collection, etc. In all cases, improved governance practices and enhanced accountability mechanisms (e.g., public transparency of budgets, customer service contracts for public utilities, adequate public asset management, clear monitoring of the performance of local governments) have become central to sound city government and municipal management. This project responds to the need to enhance knowledge and skills of local governments in the field of municipal finance, to allow them fulfill their responsibilities. Taxation requires both effective service delivery and transparent management to be sustainable and accepted by citizens. The development of tools to support municipalities in getting endogenous resources (local service taxation and integrating informality) goes in parallel with providing tools and how-to instruments to improve the management and transparency of local finances. This latter is a crucial need, as transparency and perception of local corruption is the necessary linkage between municipal sustainability and governance.
Municipalities around the world are experiencing great innovation in the field of municipal management, from collecting taxes through the mobile phone to the implementation of new management strategies to save energy, and money, in the run of public services and maintenance of essential infrastructure. This common initiative by UNCDF, UN-Habitat and FMDV has been designed to address this incipient innovation and make it available at a larger scale by bringing together central and local governments in a necessary dialogue about innovation on municipal management and finance.
The partnership will set up a platform to gather lessons learned from innovative experiences on Municipal finance and involve the UNCDF Municipal Finance initiatives in the framework of Habitat III agenda. This UN Conference will take place in Quito, Ecuador in October 2016 and the project will be part of UNCDF's contribution to the upcoming debate by providing concrete lessons learned from its own programs and experiences. A specific focus will be placed on LDCs countries and medium scale cities to make those needs more visible and understood by the international community, practitioners, partners and Member states.
Objectives
The purpose of this common initiative is to assess the needs of municipalities and central governments from LCDs countries around the issues of innovation in municipal management and finance. The project will provide a framework for the identification of innovative municipal finances in the following fields of expertise:
Transfers from central to local governmentRevenue taxManagement of municipal assetsCity borrowing and bondsTransparency and accountability as a tool to increase local revenue and better efficiency in the provision of basic services.
The project will also provide a platform for debate and visibility of those specific needs and put this discussions into the Habitat III agenda.
The project objectiveis to contribute to sustainable urban development and local democracy through capable, resourceful and empowered local governments. The strategic result is that local governments will have adequate governance structures, mechanisms and resources to fulfill responsibilities and influenceurbandevelopment agendas atall levels of interventions.
